The commentators of the Qur'an have differing opinions regarding the meaning of these letters. Further study of this issue is encouraged in "Al-Qur'an dan Tafsirnya" Volume I, specifically the commentary on the first verse of Surah al-Baqarah.
text.3:
In this verse, Allah, the All-Powerful, the All-Wise, explains that what was revealed to the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) included preaching about *tauhid*, the oneness of Allah, also about prophethood, believing in the Day of Judgment, improving oneself with noble character and distancing oneself from low and despicable things, and striving for the happiness of oneself and society – all of this was also revealed to the prophets before him. Allah says:

"And We did not send any messenger before you (O Muhammad) except that We revealed to him that, "There is no deity except Me, so worship Me." (al-Anbiya'/21: 25)

In another verse, Allah says:

"Indeed, We have revealed to you (O Muhammad) as We revealed to Noah and the prophets after him. And We revealed to Abraham, Ishmael, Isaac, Jacob, and the Descendants, Jesus, Job, Jonah, Aaron, and Solomon, and to David We gave the book [of Psalms]." (an-Nisa'/4: 163)
text.4:
In this verse, Allah explains that He is the One who controls and possesses everything in the heavens and everything on earth. This demonstrates His limitless power. He can do whatever He wills according to His iradat (will). Everything that exists must submit to Him. He is the One who regulates everything that exists, He is the Most High, there is no kingdom or power higher than Him. He is the Most Great.

To Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on earth, Allah's creation and ownership without limitation to His creatures. He is the Most Great in all His affairs, laws, and preservation. Glory be to Allah, there is no God but Him.
text.5:
In this verse, Allah explains that due to His supreme greatness, loftiness, and awe, the heavens almost crack, shatter into pieces, and collapse. The angels constantly glorify Allah, sanctifying Him from all imperfections, praising and thanking Him for all the blessings He has bestowed upon them, obedient and submissive to His commands, never committing disobedience or rebellion against Him, as Allah says:

They (the angels) glorify (Him) without ceasing, night and day. (al-Anbiya'/21: 20)

And His saying:

Who do not disobey Allah in what He commands them but do what they are commanded. (at-Tahrim/66: 6)

The angels also always beseech Allah to forgive the sins of the believers on earth, and inspire them so that they always follow the paths of goodness that lead to happiness.

An angel is likened to a light that gives life with the heat it possesses, and gives guidance with its light.

In line with the above, Allah says:

Those (angels) who carry the Throne and those around it exalt [Allah] with praise of their Lord and believe in Him and ask forgiveness for those who have believed, [saying], "Our Lord, You have encompassed all things in mercy and knowledge, so forgive those who have repented and followed Your way and protect them from the punishment of Hellfire." (Gafir/40: 7)

This fifth verse affirms that Allah is the Most Forgiving, forgiving the sins of everyone who returns and repents to Him with sincere repentance (taubat nasuha). Every creature is entitled to obtain mercy and compassion from Him. The delay and postponement of punishment and torment for the disbelievers and the disobedient is a mercy and a sign of His compassion towards them.
text.6:
In this verse, Allah explains that those who associate partners with Allah and take protectors besides Him, Allah Himself is the One who watches over their deeds, and He is the One who will give them a fitting recompense in the Hereafter for all their actions in the world. Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) is not burdened and not assigned to oversee their actions. He is only assigned to convey what Allah has commanded him, as in His saying:

"Then your duty is only to convey [the message], and it is We who will take account." (ar-Ra'd/13: 40)

Therefore, he does not need to be agitated and feel constricted in his chest if they still remain in disbelief and do not want to believe, because in any case, he does not force them to believe and obtain guidance, unless Allah wills it, as in His saying:

"Not upon you, [O Muhammad], is [to effect] their guidance, but Allah guides whom He wills." (al-Baqarah/2: 272)
text.7:
In this verse, Allah explains that the revelation sent down to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was in Arabic, in accordance with the language of the inhabitants of Mecca and its surroundings, to make it easier for them to understand the *da'wah* (call) and the warnings that Muhammad (peace be upon him) directed to them, just as every messenger who was sent used the language of his people to make it easy to provide explanations to them, as Allah says:

"And We did not send any messenger except [speaking] in the language of his people to state clearly [Our message] to them." (Ibrahim/14:4)

Even though only the inhabitants of Mecca and its surroundings are mentioned in this verse as the targets of the *da'wah* and warnings of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), it does not mean that Muhammad (peace be upon him) was sent only to the Arabs. Only the inhabitants of Mecca and its surroundings are mentioned because it is in accordance with the Prophet's position residing in Mecca at that time, while in reality Muhammad (peace be upon him) is a messenger to all of mankind, as Allah says:

"And We have not sent you, [O Muhammad], except comprehensively to mankind as a bringer of good tidings and a warner. But most of the people do not know." (Saba'/34:28)

The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said:

Abu Hurairah narrated that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said, "By Him in Whose hand is my life, anyone from amongst the Jews and the Christians who hears about me, and dies without believing in that with which I have been sent, will be from the inhabitants of Hell (Fire)." (Narrated by Muslim)

The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was not only tasked with giving warnings to the inhabitants of Mecca and the inhabitants of the surrounding countries, but also tasked with giving warnings about the Day of Judgment. The Day of Judgment is a day that is certain and there is no doubt about its coming, where on that day all creatures will be gathered to account for their actions in the world and receive rewards according to their actions.

Verse 7 ends with an affirmation that after a very thorough examination and a very careful calculation of each creature for all its actions in this world, they are divided into two groups. One group of them are among the fortunate and are admitted into Paradise, to abide therein forever. Because they believed in Allah and His Messenger and did good deeds in the world, it is only fitting that they receive a bounty from Allah, enjoying eternal pleasure in Paradise, as Allah says:

"And as for those who are blessed, they will be in Paradise, abiding therein as long as the heavens and the earth endure, except what your Lord should will - a gift uninterrupted." (Hud/11:108)

While the second group belongs to the unfortunate; they are admitted into the blazing Fire, to abide therein forever because they, while in the world, remained in disbelief in Allah, opposing what was preached by our leader, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), as Allah says:

"So as for those who are miserable, they will be in the Fire, for them therein is [violent] exhaling and inhaling. Abiding therein as long as the heavens and the earth endure, except what your Lord should will. Indeed, your Lord is an effecter of what He intends." (Hud/11:106-107)
text.8:
In this verse, Allah explains that if He willed, all of humanity would believe and become one community. However, His wisdom has dictated that the matter of faith and disbelief be left to each individual. He does not want to force all people to believe, but rather gives them the right to choose and determine their own destiny according to their own will. Blessed are those who follow the guidance of the Messenger. They are always grateful, praising Allah, and will be admitted into His mercy. And wretched are those who always oppose and refuse to follow the guidance of the Messenger; they will be punished on the Day of Judgment, and no one will help or protect them. They can blame no one but themselves, as the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"Whoever receives good should praise Allah, and whoever receives other than that should blame no one but himself." (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Dharr al-Giffari)

There are many verses similar to verse 8. Among them are Allah's words:

"And if Allah had willed, He would have made them all follow guidance." (al-An'am/6: 35)

And His words:

"And if We had willed, We could have given every soul its guidance." (as-Sajdah/32: 13)
text.9:
In this verse, Allah explains that the polytheists of Mecca have taken protectors besides Allah to help them in matters requiring assistance. They have gone astray because they take creatures as protectors who cannot bring benefit or ward off disaster for themselves, let alone for others. If they wanted a true and genuine protector, one who could bring benefit and ward off disaster, they would certainly choose Allah as their protector, the Almighty over such things, the Lord who gives life and causes death. The Lord who will resurrect them later in the Hereafter, and they should not choose weak and powerless creatures as their protectors, as Allah says:

Indeed, those you invoke besides Allah will never create [as much as] a fly, even if they gathered together for that purpose. And if the fly should steal away a bit from them, they could not recover it from him. Weak are the pursuer and pursued. (al-hajj/22: 73)
text.10:
Allah explains that whatever is disputed regarding religious matters, the decision should be returned to Allah, meaning only Allah determines what is right and what is wrong. Humans in worldly life must follow Allah's guidance in the Al-Qur'an and the guidance of the Sunnah of the Messenger, as Allah says:

"Then if you differ in anything, refer it to Allah and the Messenger, if you believe in Allah and the Last Day." (an-Nisa'/4: 59)

Whereas the one who decides the disputes of mankind in the Hereafter is solely Allah, because no creature has any power, and only Allah is the All-Powerful, as the verse states:

"Master of the Day of Judgment." (al-Fatihah/1: 4)

He is the One who will decree the judgment on the Day of Resurrection, handling the matters between those who dispute. There, it will be clearly known who is right and who is wrong, who is worthy of entering Paradise and who will be an inhabitant of Hell.

The One who possesses the attributes of giving life and causing death, decreeing judgment between two people who are in dispute, is none other than Allah, the One and Only God, not the gods besides Allah that they consider and acknowledge. To Him do humans put their trust and surrender themselves in order to be protected from all the evil schemes of their enemies, and the success or failure of their affairs is only to Allah that everything is returned, and to Him do we repent for all the sins and transgressions that we have committed. As He says:

"And to Allah return all matters." (al-Baqarah/2: 210)
text.11:
Allah explains that He is the One who created the heavens and the earth and everything in them, as well as the strange and wondrous things that amaze us, such as the vast expanse of the horizon stretching above us without any supporting pillars; therefore, He is the One who is fitting and worthy to be relied upon in all matters and to have His help and assistance sought; not their powerless gods who can do nothing. He is the One who created for mankind mates from among themselves; one is paired with another so that generations are born to populate this world. The same applies to livestock, which eventually multiply and fill life on earth.

Thus, the life of creatures on this earth becomes orderly and guaranteed for them. Sufficient nutritious food, refreshing drinks, and other blessings that must be gratefully acknowledged to achieve happiness in this world and the hereafter. All of this demonstrates the truth and power of Allah. There is nothing like Him in anything. He is All-Hearing, He hears everything that every creature says, He is All-Seeing. Nothing is hidden from Him. He sees all the deeds of His creatures, both good and evil. There is nothing that matches His power, greatness, and wisdom.

Allah created everything in pairs. This verse clearly states this. Similarly, several verses follow:

"Glory be to Him Who created all the pairs - from what the earth produces and from themselves and from what they do not know." (Yasin/36: 36)

The word of Allah:

"And it is He who spread the earth and placed therein firmly set mountains and rivers; and from all fruits He made therein pairs. He causes the night to cover the day. Indeed in that are signs for a people who give thought." (ar-Ra'd/13: 3)

And His word:

"And of all things We created two mates; perhaps you will remember." (adh-dhariyat/51: 49)

According to scientific studies, it is not only living things that are in pairs, but inanimate objects are also in pairs. Using science and sophisticated equipment available today, it is possible to know about the pairs from atoms to clouds. The atom, which was previously thought to be the smallest and indivisible form, turns out to be paired. Atoms consist of electrons and protons. Protons, which are positively charged, are surrounded by several negatively charged electron particles. The electrical charge in both groups of particles is very balanced.

Plants also have pairs for their growth and development. Previously, humans did not know that plants also have different male and female sexes. Fruit is the final product of higher plant reproduction. The stage preceding the fruit is the flower, which has male and female organs, namely stamens and pistils. When pollen is delivered to the pistil, it will produce fruit, which then grows, until it finally ripens and releases its seeds. Therefore, all fruits reflect the existence of male and female organs, a fact mentioned in the Al-Qur'an.

There are plants that have stamens and pistils that are united within their partner; and in pollination, it does not need a male from another flower. However, there are also those who only have one of them, so to produce, it needs a partner from another flower. Only Allah is not paired.
text.12:
In this verse, Allah explains that He is the One who possesses the treasures of the heavens and the earth. The good and bad of everything is in His hands. Whoever He bestows mercy upon, no one can prevent Him. Conversely, whoever He does not grant mercy to, no one can bring it to them. He is the One who expands sustenance for whomever He wills, and He is also the One who restricts sustenance for whomever He wills. All of this happens according to His wise wisdom, based on His vast power and His knowledge that encompasses all things.

The Islamic religion commands its adherents to work and strive to earn a livelihood for their life in this world. As for the results, they are in accordance with Allah's wisdom; some succeed in acquiring abundant wealth as a test, while others only obtain a little sustenance as a trial for their lives. As Abu Bakar al-Jazairi stated in his Tafsir, *Aisar at-Tafasir*:

Allah expands sustenance for whomever He wills as a test, and restricts it as a trial.
text.13:
In this verse, Allah explains that He has ordained the religion for Muhammad, peace be upon him, and his people, just as He had also enjoined it upon Noah and the prophets who came after him, namely Abraham, Moses, and Jesus.

The religious law (syariat) enjoined upon Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, and the prophets before him share similarities in the fundamental principles of faith (akidah), such as belief in Allah, the prophethood of the messengers, and the conviction of the Day of Reckoning or the Day of Judgment.

Meanwhile, the foundation of religion that is the main mission of the messengers is to worship Allah and not associate partners with Him. Allah says:

And We did not send any messenger before you (Muhammad) except that We revealed to him that, "There is no deity except Me, so worship Me." (al-Anbiya'/21: 25)

The non-fundamental differences between the messages of the prophets are in the area of religious law (syariat) that is of a *furu'iyyah* (branch) nature. Several forms of worship and their details, according to the development of the times, needs, and the benefit of mankind. Allah says:

To each of you We prescribed a law and a method. (al-Ma'idah/5: 48)

A Hadith of the Prophet narrated by Abu Hurairah reads:

The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said, "I am the most worthy of Jesus, son of Mary, in this world and the Hereafter." The companions asked, "Why, O Messenger of Allah?" The Prophet replied, "The Prophets are brothers from various lineages. Their mothers are many, but their religion is one. And there is no prophet between us (Prophet Muhammad and Jesus)." (Narrated by Ahmad and Muslim)

Allah only mentions the names of the prophets above because of their higher position compared to other prophets who are not mentioned, having great and heavy responsibilities, and because of their steadfastness in facing trials and difficulties caused by their people, so that they received the title *Ulul Azmi* from Allah. By mentioning the names of Moses and Jesus, it is hoped that the Jews and Christians can realize and be attracted to the religion brought by Muhammad, peace be upon him, a Heavenly religion that has many similarities with their religion, which is clearly stated in the Torah and the Gospel, especially regarding monotheism, prayer (salat), alms (zakat), fasting, pilgrimage (hajj), and good morals such as keeping promises, honesty, maintaining kinship, and so on.

Allah commands that the Islamic religion brought by Muhammad, peace be upon him, be maintained and upheld completely; its followers are forbidden to disagree among themselves, which can lead to division and damage unity. Allah's word:

The believers are but brothers, so make settlement between your brothers. And fear Allah that you may receive mercy. (al-hujurat/49: 10)

And His word:

And hold firmly to the rope of Allah all together and do not become divided. (Ali 'Imran/3: 103)

It seems difficult for the polytheists to embrace the religion of monotheism, namely the Islamic religion brought by Muhammad, peace be upon him, and to abandon their polytheistic religion and worship of idols that have been inherited from their ancestors; their strength has been immortalized in the Qur'an.

Indeed, we found our fathers upon a religion, and we are guided by their traces. (az-Zukhruf/43: 22)

Indeed, not everyone can fulfill the call to embrace the Islamic religion brought by Muhammad, peace be upon him, but Allah determines His servants whom He wills and guides them so that they embrace the Islamic religion.
text.14:
In this verse, Allah explains that the People of the Book, both Jews and Christians, after knowing the truth of the messengers sent to them, then split into several groups, as Allah describes in His word:

"Indeed, those who have divided their religion and become sects - you, [O Muhammad], are not [associated] with them in anything. Their affair is only with Allah, who then will inform them about what they used to do." (al-An'am/6: 159)

They did so because of envy and hatred among them, resulting in conflicts between sects that were difficult to overcome and resolve. They accused each other; the Jews were convinced of the truth of their stance and beliefs, while the Christians believed that the Jews had no stance or beliefs. Conversely, the Jews considered the Christians to have no stance, as Allah says:

"The Jews say, "The Christians have nothing [true] to stand on," and the Christians say, "The Jews have nothing [true] to stand on,"" (al-Baqarah/2: 113)

If there had not been a prior decree from Allah regarding the postponement of retribution and punishment for those who oppose and violate Allah's commands until the time He has determined (the Day of Judgment), they would have been destroyed in this world and would not need to be delayed until the Hereafter.

Division among mankind is widespread, not only occurring among the People of the Book, but also among Muslims themselves. If the People of the Book experienced much division in the field of aqidah (creed), Islamic groups experienced many disputes in the fields of fiqh (jurisprudence), muamalat (transactions), and marriage, which caused division among Muslims. The command to unite must be truly realized by Muslims, because the negative impact of this division is the weakening of the unity and solidarity of the ummah, so that our bargaining position in various positions and fields in the international world becomes weak.

Verse 14 is closed with a reaffirmation that the Jews and Christians who inherited the Torah and the Gospel from their ancestors, who during the time of the Prophet Muhammad saw the Islamic da'wah (call), became doubtful about the truth of their books and truly shook their faith. This is not surprising because, besides their faith in the Divine Books not being deep, they embraced religion only because they followed their ancestors.
text.15:
In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad (saw) to call upon his people not to be divided like the People of the Book, to unite in embracing the religion of monotheism pioneered by the prophets, namely the religion of Islam that he brought, and to remain steadfast in facing them. He should never be influenced by their doubts about the true religion that has been prescribed for him. He must always affirm his stance that he still believes in everything that Allah has sent down from the heavens, such as the Torah, the Gospel, and the Psalms, and he does not deny any of it. The Prophet Muhammad is also commanded to be just among them in establishing laws and so on, without reducing or adding to what Allah has prescribed for him, and to convey what he has been commanded to convey.

This verse also explains that Allah is your Lord and our Lord. He is the only one who must be worshipped, who must be believed with full understanding. There is no God but Allah. For us are our deeds, good or bad, for which we are responsible, rewarded or punished, and for you are your deeds. We will not be happy because of your good deeds, nor will we be harmed because of your bad deeds. Each is responsible for his actions. In line with this verse is the word of Allah:

And if they deny you (Muhammad), then say, "For me is my deed, and for you is your deed. You are disassociated from what I do, and I am disassociated from what you do." (Yunus/10: 41)

Thus, there should be no more disputes between the Muslims and the polytheists, the right and the truth have become clear. Whoever still rebels and does not want to believe means he is denying. In due time, it will be clear and visible who is right among the adherents of religion because Allah will gather all mankind later on the Day of Judgment, and there He will make the fairest decision on what was disputed, as Allah says:

Say, "Our Lord will bring us together; then He will judge between us in truth. And He is the All-Just, the All-Knowing." (Saba'/34: 26)

To Him all mankind will return after death and be held accountable for all deeds in the world. All mankind will receive rewards according to their respective deeds, as Allah says:

So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it, And whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it. (az-Zalzalah/99: 7-9)

Wahbah Zuhaili in his tafsir al-Munir concludes ten commands and prohibitions of Allah not only for the Messenger of Allah but also for all Muslims. The ten commands and prohibitions are:

1.  The command to the Prophet to continue preaching and conveying his message.

2.  *Istiqamah* (steadfastness) in its delivery.

3.  The prohibition for the Messenger not to follow the desires of the polytheists of Mecca or the People of the Book, to follow their worship.

4.  The command to believe and declare faith in the heavenly books revealed by Allah.

5.  The command to be just among the *Muhajirin* and when facing disputes that occur among them.

6.  The command to declare that only Allah is worthy of worship, there is no God but Him.

7.  The command to declare to the People of the Book that each is responsible for his deeds and the good and bad rewards of those deeds.

8.  The command to declare that there is no enmity between the Prophet and the People of the Book, because the truth of Allah is clearly visible.

9.  The command to declare that Allah will gather the Muslims and the People of the Book in Padang Mahsyar (the Plain of Gathering) to face the judgment of Allah.

10. Only to Allah will all creatures return.
text.16:
In this verse, Allah explains that those who still dispute the truth of Allah's religion, even though that religion has been well-received by society, their efforts and arguments will be in vain. They are angered by Allah because of their boldness in denying the truth of Islam, and they will be punished in the Hereafter for their arrogance in abandoning the true religion whose truth can be proven.

It is narrated that the Jews said to the believers, "O believers! You have all said that taking and accepting what has been agreed upon is better than taking and accepting what is disputed. The prophethood of Moses and his Torah have been accepted and agreed upon as true, while the prophethood of Muhammad is still disputed and contested. So the Jewish religion is the one that is fitting and worthy to be taken and accepted." To refute their argument, Allah presented the argument that the obligation to believe in and trust the truth of Moses is because of the miracles that Allah gave him which show and prove its truth. Some of the miracles given to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) could be witnessed by the Jews themselves. Therefore, it is obligatory upon all of us to acknowledge and believe in the prophethood of Muhammad (peace be upon him).
text.17:
In this verse, Allah explains that He has sent down His books to His prophets, containing undeniable truth, far from falsehood, and all containing goodness. He gives the command to act justly as a reference for determining punishments in judging those accused of wrongdoing and punishing them with the punishments that have been stipulated in His Book. Allah says:

"Indeed, We have sent Our messengers with clear proofs, and revealed with them the Scripture and the balance (justice) that mankind may keep up justice." (al-Hadid/57: 25)

The conclusion of this verse encourages us to do good and be just for the happiness of the hereafter and to avoid worldly temptations. Because it is unknown when this world will end, we must certainly obey and follow the guidance of the Qur'an, always act justly among fellow human beings, practice what is commanded, always be vigilant against the possibility of Allah's call coming suddenly, and then there is no more opportunity to do good, he will be at a loss, and on the Day of Judgment he will regret wasting the opportunity to do good deeds. The Prophet (saw) said:

The Messenger of Allah (saw) said, "There is no one who dies but he regrets." The Companions asked, "What is their regret, O Messenger of Allah?" The Prophet replied, "If he is a doer of good, then he regrets that his good deeds did not increase. If he is not a doer of good, then he regrets that he did not have the opportunity to free himself from that evil." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi)
text.18:
It is narrated that on one occasion, the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, mentioned the Day of Judgment, and at that time there were polytheists present. They asked mockingly and denying the coming of the Day of Judgment, "When is the Day of Judgment?" Then this verse was revealed. The narration above tells that those who did not believe in the occurrence of the Day of Judgment mocked the Prophet and denied him. They wanted the Day of Judgment to come quickly to prove who was right, them or Muhammad and his companions?

In contrast, the believers feel afraid and anxious about the coming of the Day of Judgment. They do not yet know what their fate will be on that day. They must account for their deeds in the world and receive good and bad rewards for their actions. In line with this verse is Allah's saying:

"And those who give what they give with their hearts full of fear (because they know) that they will return to their Lord." (al-Mu'minun/23: 60)

This verse concludes with a firm statement that those who dispute and reject the existence of the Day of Judgment are those who are misguided, on the wrong path, far from the truth.

Because belief in the Day of Judgment is one of the pillars of faith, denying the Day of Judgment means denying the truth of Allah, because true justice can only be obtained by humans on the Day of Judgment. There is so much injustice on this earth, where else will those who are oppressed obtain their rights if not in the court of Allah.

A person who desires the Hereafter, in the sense of believing in it and preparing to face it, is a person who has a long-term vision, while those who deny the Day of Judgment, who consider their life to end with their death, are people whose vision of life is narrow. They will never feel spiritual satisfaction, because they are busy pursuing worldly pleasures.

One of the characteristics that distinguishes between religious teachings and human thought that has been applied by humans in this world is the belief in the Hereafter or the Day of Judgment, because it can be said that the core of faith in Allah is faith in the Hereafter, the place and time where humans must account for all their deeds in the world. The news about the Day of Judgment and the resurrection of the dead will surely become a reality.

Allah is the creator of the heavens and the earth, He is able and powerful to destroy them and revive the dead. As Allah says:

"And He is the One who begins creation, then repeats it, and that is easier for Him." (ar-Rum/30: 27)
text.19:
Allah explains that He Himself is always doing good to His servants. He gives them beneficial things, keeps them away from threatening disasters, bestows sustenance upon His believing and disbelieving servants without distinction between them. Allah also expands and restricts sustenance to whomever He wills as a test for the rich in their attitude towards the poor and a test for the poor in their relationship with the rich, so that the relationship between one person and another becomes good because they need each other. As Allah says:

*Is it they who would portion out the mercy of your Lord? It is We who have apportioned among them their livelihood in the life of this world and have raised some of them above others in degrees [of rank] that they may make use of one another. But the mercy of your Lord is better than whatever they accumulate.* (az-Zukhruf/43: 32)

Furthermore, it is explained that Allah is All-Powerful and All-Mighty, He acts according to His will, and no one can prevent or hinder what He wills.
text.20:
This verse explains that whoever desires reward through their deeds and efforts, Allah will make it easy for them to perform righteous deeds, and then He will reward their deeds, one good deed with ten good deeds up to many times more according to Allah's will. Conversely, whoever expects from their efforts the luxuries of the world in all its forms and does not expect any deeds or rewards in the Hereafter, then Allah will give them as much as has been determined for them, but they will not obtain any reward in the Hereafter because the deed is in accordance with their intention, and for each person the reward for their deed is in accordance with their intention, as the Prophet (saw) said:

"Verily, deeds are according to intentions, and verily, every person will have what they intended." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Qatadah said, "Indeed, Allah gives rewards to those whose deeds are intended for the Hereafter in addition to worldly pleasures according to His will. Allah does not give rewards in the Hereafter to those who perform deeds with the intention of obtaining only worldly pleasures." This is in line with Allah's saying:

"Whoever desires the immediate (worldly) life - We hasten for him from it what We will to whom We intend. Then We have prepared for him Hell, which he will [enter to] burn, censured and banished. But whoever desires the Hereafter and strives for it with [due] effort while he is a believer - then those are the ones whose endeavor is ever appreciated [by Allah]." (al-Isra'/17: 18-19)
text.21:
In this verse, Allah explains that the polytheists do not follow the Islamic religion prescribed by Allah, but rather follow what is outlined by their devils, whether in the form of jinn or humans. They forbid things according to their desires, such as forbidding camels with slit ears, and permitting carrion, blood, gambling, and so on. Likewise, they continue to practice things that demonstrate their error, as they did during the Jahiliyyah period. Even so, they are still given the opportunity to repent, because Allah has prescribed a provision, namely the postponement of punishment for them until the Day of Resurrection. If not, they would have been destroyed, as Allah says:

"Nay, the Hour is the time promised for them (for their punishment), and the Hour will be more grievous and more bitter." (al-Qamar/54: 46)

They have wronged themselves by inventing things that Allah has not prescribed. They will be admitted into Hell, a place full of painful torment and the worst of destinations.
text.22:
In this verse, Allah explains that the wrongdoers appear fearful, overshadowed by the consequences of the various evil deeds they committed in the world, and the punishment that is the recompense for their evil deeds will surely befall them. As for those who believe in Allah and are obedient to what He has commanded and forbidden, they will be admitted into Paradise, a place filled with beautiful gardens, enjoying all the beauty and pleasures within it according to their desires, whether in the form of food, drink, or scenery that has never been seen by the eye, heard by the ear, or conceived in the heart of a human being. All of this is a great favor bestowed by Allah upon them, which is far greater than any luxury that has ever existed in the world, as Allah says:

"That is the bounty of Allah; He grants it to whom He wills. And Allah is the possessor of great bounty." (al-Hadid/57: 21)
text.23:
In this verse, Allah explains that what has been announced regarding the bestowal of blessings, pleasures, and honor in the Hereafter for His believing and righteous servants is good news conveyed in this world so that it is clear to them that this will certainly become a reality. Furthermore, Allah commands Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) to convey to his people that in carrying out the task of calling to and conveying the true religion, he does not ask for any reward whatsoever, but he only hopes for the love and affection of the Muslims towards himself, his relatives, and other Muslims.

Whoever does good, obeys, and is compliant with the commands of Allah and His Messenger, Allah will multiply the good for him. One good deed is rewarded with at least ten good deeds, up to seven hundred good deeds or even more, as a mercy and favor from Allah, as Allah says:

"Indeed, Allah does not do injustice, [even] as much as an atom's weight; while if there is a good deed, He multiplies it and gives from Himself a great reward." (an-Nisa'/4: 40)

Allah says:

"Whoever comes [on the Day of Judgement] with a good deed will have ten times the like thereof [to his credit]..." (al-An'am/6: 160)

Allah says:

"The example of those who spend their wealth in the way of Allah is like a seed [of grain] which grows seven spikes; in each spike is a hundred grains. And Allah multiplies [His reward] for whom He wills. And Allah is all-Encompassing and Knowing." (al-Baqarah/2: 261)

Furthermore, this verse 23 is concluded with an explanation that Allah forgives the sins of His servants, no matter how numerous, and multiplies the reward for good deeds, even if they are few, because He is the Most Forgiving and Most Appreciative.
text.24:
In this verse, Allah rejects the accusation of the polytheists of Mecca that Muhammad (peace be upon him) fabricated lies against Allah. This is a very evil deed. If Allah had willed, He could have certainly sealed your heart because such an act is only committed by polytheists.

But the sunnah (established practice) of Allah has been and will continue to be in effect, that He always destroys and obliterates falsehood and strengthens the truth and plants the reality of the truth among mankind according to His established decree. That is why the religion brought by Muhammad (peace be upon him) day by day becomes stronger and more established, more widespread, and more and more followers embrace it.

Allah is All-Knowing of all that is stored in the hearts; nothing is hidden from Him. Therefore, everything happens based on Allah's vast knowledge, encompassing everything. Therefore, their accusation against the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), who they considered to have fabricated lies about Allah, is known to Him and its falsehood has been proven in this verse.
text.25:
In this verse, Allah explains that He is the One who accepts the repentance of His servants, forgiving sinful deeds and wrongdoings. Sayyidina 'Ali was once asked about repentance. He replied, "Repentance has six conditions."

1. Regretting the acts of disobedience that were committed in the past.

2. Performing the obligatory acts of worship that have been neglected.

3. Returning the rights of those who have been unjustly taken from them.

4. Forcing oneself to taste the bitterness of obedience just as one tasted the sweetness of disobedience.

5. Subjugating one's desires in obedience just as one indulged them in committing disobedience.

6. Weeping as a replacement for the laughter that was once indulged in.

This verse is concluded with the explanation that Allah is the Most Forgiving of all sins and knows everything that His servants do, whether it be good or evil, and then they will be rewarded with blessings and punishment.
text.26:
In this verse, Allah explains that He always answers the (prayers) of those who believe and do righteous deeds, and increases for them reward and bounty, as Allah says:

"And your Lord says, "Call upon Me; I will respond to you." (Gafir/40: 60)

Allah says:

"And when My servants ask you, [O Muhammad], concerning Me - indeed I am near. I respond to the invocation of the supplicant when he calls upon Me." (al-Baqarah/2: 186)
text.27:
In this verse, Allah explains that He will not give His servants abundant sustenance if that provision could lead them to arrogance and pride, as Allah says:

"Nay! Verily, man does transgress all bounds (in wickedness and disobedience). Because he sees himself self-sufficient." (al-'Alaq/96: 6-7)

Allah provides sustenance to His servants in a measured amount, according to His will and in accordance with His wisdom. With Allah's attribute of Rahman (Most Gracious), He continues to provide sustenance even if a person does not believe, even when people forget their Lord, that is when Allah pours out even more sustenance. If they still do not give thanks and are immersed in pleasure, then Allah will inflict His punishment, as Allah says:

"So, when they forgot (the warning) with which they had been reminded, We opened to them the gates of every (pleasant) thing, until in what they rejoiced, We seized them suddenly, and behold! They were plunged into destruction with deep regrets." (al-An'am/6: 44)

Based on the explanation above, it can be said that a person's wealth is not an indicator that Allah loves him, but wealth is actually a test for a person's faith. An example of how a person behaves towards his wealth can be seen in whether he uses it to benefit himself and others, because of the involvement of other people's rights in his wealth and as a sign of gratitude to the giver of wealth, or whether he uses that wealth only for his own pleasure and claims that his wealth was obtained through his own efforts, thus forgetting Allah who gave the wealth. Allah says:

"And know that your possessions and your children are but a trial and that surely with Allah is a mighty reward." (al-Anfal/8: 28)

In this case, Qarun (Korah) and Pharaoh are real examples, because their wealth and glory caused them to be arrogant towards Allah.

Abu Hani' al-Khaulani said, "I heard 'Amr bin Khurait and others say that this verse (verse 27) was revealed to the ahlusuffah (the people of the veranda of the Prophet's mosque in Medina); they longed to have (piles of) possessions, they longed for the splendor of the world."
text.28:
In this verse, Allah explains that He is the One who sends down rain from the sky, helping those who have despaired because the water they hoped would come from the sky has not arrived. He is the One who blesses the rain and brings many benefits, making the land fertile. He is the One who controls the affairs of His servants, giving them benefits. He is the One who deserves to be praised for the mercy He has bestowed upon them.

Qatadah said, "It is narrated that a man said to 'Umar bin al-Khaththab, "The rain has not fallen, and the people have despaired, O Amirul Mukminin." Umar replied, "You will be blessed with rain," then he recited this verse.
text.29:
In this verse, Allah explains that among His signs of power and greatness is His creation of the heavens and the earth, and what is scattered in both, such as crawling and moving creatures, including humans, jinn, and all animals with their various forms, patterns, and colors.

Allah is able to gather mankind on the Day of Judgment, both those who came earlier and those who came later, as well as other creatures; in the Padang Mahsyar (the Gathering Place) He will then recompense them with perfect justice. As Allah says:

And (remember) the Day We set the mountains in motion, and you will see the earth leveled, and We will gather them all together so as to leave none of them behind. (al-Kahf/18: 47)

If we pay attention to the verse above, we feel that Allah is explaining the existence of other living beings in outer space. Before discussing the verse above, it is necessary to first consider the related verse below:

And He has subjected to you whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth, all from Him. Surely in that are signs for a people who reflect. (al-Jatsiyah/45: 13)

The verse above mentions the word "subjected." This word can be interpreted to mean that humans can utilize celestial bodies, such as planets and stars. For example, the moon and the sun have regular orbits. The regularity of these orbits is used by humans to create time markers or calendars and other things for their life's needs. Another example is the arrival of iron from outer space, which is clearly stated in Surah al-Hadid/57: 25.

It is clearly mentioned that Allah has created galaxies, planets, stars, and other celestial bodies, and scattered upon them, among other things, living creatures as a result of His creation. This means that it is very possible that He sends creations from one planet to another. The same is true of two other verses that discuss livestock being sent down from outer space (al-An'am/6:143 and az-Zumar/39: 6).

From a scientific point of view, many proofs point to what the Qur'an explains. On August 7, 1996, NASA (the United States space agency) researchers announced the discovery of microscopic life on Mars three billion years ago. Although many oppose this theory, the findings of the Galileo spacecraft regarding the existence of a red-colored sea under the ice layer on Jupiter's satellite, Europe, are very promising. In the near future, the oldest question that has always been embedded in the human mind will be answered: "Is there life up there? Or are we on this earth the only living beings in the universe?"

If there is indeed life up there, where can they be found? Our first guess is on the planets that are there. On the "earths" that exist in the galaxies in the universe. This is reflected Quranically in Surah ath-Thalaq/65: 12 which states, "It is Allah who has created seven heavens and of the earth, the like thereof..." Thus, because there are millions of galaxies, Allah also created billions of earths, scattered throughout the universe. Meanwhile, the word "earth" used here indicates a planet that has life. By holding on to the statements of the Qur'an and a little evidence obtained by science, we come to the conclusion that extraterrestrial beings do exist.

The next question is, will we be able to find them? Allah gives an indication in Surah Fussilat/41: 53 "We will show them Our signs in the horizons and within themselves…." This indication gives hope that at some point we will be able to meet extraterrestrial life, including intelligent beings.
text.30:
In this verse, Allah explains that what befalls mankind in the world in the form of calamities, illnesses, and other things, is a consequence of their own actions, the acts of disobedience they have committed, and the sins they have done, as stated in the Prophet's (saw) saying:

'Ali said, "Shall I inform you about the most excellent verse in the Qur'an as the Prophet (saw) conveyed to us? (The Prophet (saw) recited Allah's saying) "And whatever of misfortune befalls you, it is because of what your hands have earned. And He pardons much." (Ash-Shura 42:30) O 'Ali, I will explain this verse to you, "Whatever of misfortune befalls you" that is from illness and punishment or calamities in the world, "is because of what your hands have earned." (Narrated by Ahmad)

No fatigue, illness, distress, sadness, injustice, hardship, even a thorn that pricks a Muslim, but that Allah will erase his sins with it. (Narrated by al-Bukhari)

The arrival of illness or calamity is caused by the actions of humans themselves. But on the other hand, illness or calamity can erase sins as in the hadith above. It depends on how humans respond, whether with patience or despair.

This verse concludes with a firm statement that Allah forgives the majority of the mistakes that His servants have made as a great mercy bestowed by Allah upon His servants, because if not, mankind would surely be destroyed according to the accumulation of sins they have committed, as Allah says:

And if Allah were to punish men for their wrongdoing, He would not leave on earth a single moving (living) creature, but He defers them for an appointed term. (an-Nahl/16: 61)

And His saying:

And if Allah were to punish men for what they have earned, He would not leave a single moving (living) creature on the surface of the earth, but He defers them for a specified term. (Fathir/35: 45)
text.31:
In this verse, Allah explains that humans will not be able to escape or evade Allah's punishment in this world, no matter where they are. They will not find any protector, because only Allah can protect them from the punishment that will befall them due to the sins they have committed. They will not have any helper besides Allah when they receive punishment. Therefore, humans should distance themselves from sin and not disobey His commands, because no one can reject Allah's punishment when He has inflicted it upon His servants. If sinful people are not punished in this world, do not think that it is because of someone's power or might, but rather because Allah wills it so that they may receive a more severe and painful punishment in the Hereafter, as Allah says:

And let not the disbelievers ever think that [because] We extend their time [of enjoyment] it is better for them. We only extend it for them so that they may increase in sin, and for them is a humiliating punishment. (Ali 'Imran/3: 178)
text.32:
In this verse, Allah explains that part of the signs of His power, greatness, and might is His subjugation of the sea for mankind, so that ships can sail on the sea like great mountains or a village on water.

This verse likens ships sailing to mountains. This verse also indicates that mountains are actually moving, something difficult for the common person to grasp, but something already accepted in geology. As geologists often say, mountains are actually floating like ships floating on the ocean. In this verse, Allah actually shows that sailing ships are like mountains, which is certainly difficult for the common person to understand. To the common person, mountains appear stationary. Mountains (in this case, as part of the continents) are in fact floating on the asthenosphere and moving like ships sailing (see explanation in Juz 20, An-Naml/27: 88). As is known, it was only in the decade of the sixties of the 20th century that the theory of continental drift, whose origins began in the early 20th century, together with the theory of mid-ocean ridge spreading, underpinned the theory of plate tectonics discovered by scientists.
text.33:
If Allah had willed, the ships that sailed would not have been able to sail again. He would have withheld the wind that propelled the ships to move and sail, and the ships would have remained on the surface of the water, unable to move forward or backward.

Those who can understand and realize this are those who have a broad perspective, are patient and obedient to Allah's commands, and are always grateful for the blessings that Allah has bestowed upon them. Disasters that occur in a place, such as earthquakes, landslides, waves that sweep away and destroy, and others, are considered by some people to be merely natural events that have no connection whatsoever with the power of Allah. Allah says:

"And how many signs within the heavens and earth do they pass over while they, therefrom, are turning away." (Yusuf/12: 105)

This verse is a continuation of the previous verse (ash-Shura/42: 32), that after successfully floating on the water, traditional ships require wind energy as a driver. With the wind, sailing ships can be propelled and controlled through the use of sails and rudders. If the wind stops blowing, the ship practically cannot move. Without wind, ocean waves will also stop.
text.34: This verse explains that besides Allah having the power to hold back the wind so that ships cannot move from their place, He also has the power to destroy the ship by sending a hurricane that makes the sailing ship sway, with an uncertain direction, unable to reach its intended destination, and eventually sink to the bottom of the sea due to its passengers wallowing in sin. However, this rarely happens because Allah has forgiven and pardoned most of them, so they are safe on their journey across the vast sea to their intended destination.
text.35: In this verse, Allah explains that the things described above demonstrate His power and might; may those who constantly argue and refuse to acknowledge Allah's power realize that the only One who can provide benefit and bring harm is Allah, and if He wills, no one can escape or be spared from the punishment He has decreed.
text.36:
In this verse, Allah explains that the pleasures of human life, whether in the form of wealth, abundant sustenance, offspring, and so on, are insignificant and of little value because no matter how much wealth is accumulated, the time to possess it is limited. In due time, separation will occur because if humans do not leave it, then the things themselves will leave humans. Meanwhile, the reward and blessings that are with Allah are far better than the pleasures and grandeur of this world, because what is with Allah is eternal and everlasting, while the pleasures of the world are all transient and will vanish. This verse concludes with a firm statement that eternal and everlasting pleasure is only for those who believe in Allah and His Messenger, those who trust and surrender themselves to the Lord who has cared for and done good to them.

Al-Qurthubi, in his tafsir, quotes a narration from 'Ali who said that when Abu Bakar collected wealth from Bani Murrah, he donated all the money for good causes, hoping for Allah's pleasure. His actions were criticized by the polytheists, while the disbelievers blamed his actions, so verses 36 and 37 of this surah were revealed.
text.37:
In this verse, Allah explains that those who will attain eternal pleasure in the afterlife are those who avoid major sins such as murder, adultery, and theft, and refrain from things that are not justified by Islamic law (syarak), common sense, and noble morals, whether in words or deeds. Likewise, those who, when their anger arises, remain silent and restrain their anger, forgive those who caused their anger, and have not even a trace of resentment in their hearts. It is narrated that the Messenger of Allah (saw) never defended his own interests except when the laws of Allah were violated and insulted.

The quality of forgiveness is a quality close to piety (taqwa) and is indeed commanded by Allah, as He says:

"And to forego [the full amount of the dower] is nearer to righteousness." (al-Baqarah/2: 237)

And His saying:

"Take what is given freely, enjoin what is good, and turn away from the ignorant." (al-A'raf/7: 199)
text.38:
This verse explains that those who welcome Allah's call to His religion, such as acknowledging His Oneness and sanctifying His Essence from worship other than Him, establishing the obligatory prayers on time perfectly to cleanse the heart from false beliefs and abstaining from reprehensible deeds, both apparent and unseen, always consulting each other to determine their stance in facing complex and important matters, all of them will obtain eternal pleasure in the Hereafter. In a similar verse, Allah says:

"And consult with them in the matter." (Ali 'Imran/3: 159)

Likewise, spending sustenance in the way of Allah, spending it in ways that are useful and beneficial for the individual, society, nation, and country. They will also obtain eternal pleasure in the Hereafter. In another verse, Allah says:

"O you who have believed, spend from that which We have provided for you." (al-Baqarah/2: 254)

And His saying:

"O you who have believed, spend from the good things which you have earned." (al-Baqarah/2: 267)
text.39:
In this verse, Allah explains that among the characteristics of those who will attain eternal happiness in the afterlife are those who, when treated arbitrarily by others, will defend themselves and retaliate against those who have wronged them, provided that the self-defense does not exceed the injustice that befell them. In this self-defense, they will receive help from Allah, as stated in His word:

"That is so. And whoever retaliates with the equivalent of that with which he was harmed and then is tyrannized - Allah will surely aid him." (al-hajj/22: 60)
text.40:
In this verse, Allah explains that the act of self-defense carried out by someone who is oppressed by another should be directed at the perpetrator of the oppression and be proportionate to the severity of the oppression. Excessive retaliation or self-defense is not permitted in Islam, as stated in Allah's words:

"And whoever attacks you, then attack him in the manner he attacked you." (al-Baqarah/2: 194)

In another verse, Allah says:

"And if you punish [an oppressor], punish him with an equivalent of that with which you were harmed. But if you are patient, it is better for those who are patient." (an-Nahl/16: 126)

In the current situation, those who are oppressed by others may not be able to immediately defend themselves or demand their rights from those who oppress them due to various limitations. Therefore, they can seek help from the authorities who can take action to defend their rights, such as the police, the courts, and so on. It should be remembered that a person's rights must be defended; one should not remain silent when others seize their rights. There are many hadith that explain about rights, such as:

"Whoever is killed defending his property is a martyr. Whoever is killed defending his life, family, and religion is a martyr." (Narrated by Abu Dawud and at-Tirmidhi)

Even so, this verse also encourages us not to retaliate against the evil of others, but to forgive and treat well those who do evil to us because Allah will reward those who forgive the mistakes of others. Furthermore, forgiving others is an expiation for sins. Allah says:

"And wounds [inflicted on one another] are [subject to] legal retribution. But whoever remits [his right of retaliation] as charity, it is an expiation for him [of his sins]." (al-Ma'idah/5: 45)

Verse 40 concludes with a reaffirmation that Allah does not like those who are unjust and who exceed the limits in retaliating for the evil they have experienced.
text.41: In this verse, Allah explains that those who act in self-defense against persecution or a crime that befalls them, there is no legal recourse to prosecute them and they are not sinful because they do so based on right. But those who act unjustly, commit evil on earth, and transgress in giving retribution, it is they who can be prosecuted and will receive a painful torment and punishment in the Hereafter.
text.42:
In this verse, Allah rejects the accusation of the polytheists of Mecca that Muhammad (peace be upon him) fabricated lies against Allah. This is a very evil deed. If Allah had willed, He could have sealed your heart shut because such an act is only committed by polytheists.

But the sunnah of Allah has been and will continue to be in effect, that He always destroys and obliterates falsehood and strengthens the truth, and plants the reality of the truth among mankind according to His established decree. That is why the religion brought by Muhammad (peace be upon him) is becoming stronger and more established day by day, spreading more widely, and increasing in the number of its followers.

Allah is All-Knowing of all that is hidden in the hearts; nothing is hidden from Him. Therefore, everything happens based on Allah's vast knowledge, encompassing all things. Therefore, their accusation against the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), who was considered to have fabricated lies about Allah, is known to Him and its falsehood has been proven in this verse.
text.43:
In this verse, Allah explains that those who are patient and forgive the evil deeds done by others against them, while they are capable of retaliating, have done something excellent and are entitled to receive a great reward.

It is narrated by Abu Hurairah that a man insulted Abu Bakar, while the Prophet was sitting with him, smiling. The insults were so numerous that Abu Bakar retaliated. Then the Prophet became angry and got up from his seat. Abu Bakar followed him and said, "O Messenger of Allah, he insulted me while you were sitting (watching), when I retaliated, you became angry and got up (leaving me)." The Messenger then replied, "Indeed, (when you were being insulted) an angel was with you, retaliating against the insults of that person. When you retaliated, Satan was present (there), so I did not want to sit with Satan." Then the Messenger said, "O Abu Bakar, there are 3 things that are all true, namely:

1. A servant is wronged, then he forgives his oppressor, then Allah will honor him and grant him victory over his enemy.

2. A man who gives a gift with the intention of strengthening kinship ties will be given abundant additional sustenance by Allah.

3. People who beg with the intention of enriching themselves will have their sustenance reduced by Allah."
text.44:
In this verse, Allah explains that whatever He wills will certainly come to pass, and no one can prevent it; conversely, what He does not will will not happen. Whoever has been given guidance by Allah, no one can lead them astray, and whoever has been left astray by Allah, because they constantly commit evil, no one can guide them to the right path, which will help them achieve happiness and good fortune. Allah says:

"And whoever He leaves astray - never will you find for him a protecting guide." (al-Kahf/18: 17)

The disbelievers in the Hereafter, when they see and witness the torment before their eyes, will wish they could return to the world to do good and believe. They will say, "Is there any way for us to return to the world?" Even if they could return to the world, they would still not believe and do good; they would still violate Allah's prohibitions. This is also described by Allah in another verse with His saying:

"If you could but see when they are made to stand before the Fire and will say, 'Oh, would that we could be returned [to life on earth] and not deny the signs of our Lord and be among the believers.' Rather, what they concealed before has [now] appeared to them. But even if they were returned, they would surely revert to that which they were forbidden. And indeed, they are liars." (al-An'am/6: 27-28)
text.45:
In this verse, Allah explains that when these disbelievers are brought before Hell, they are terrified and feel humiliated because they know and are certain that it is the result of the transgressions and sins they have committed. They are aware of the greatness and power of the Lord they have disobeyed. They cannot stare at the blazing fire of Hell; they look at it with a languid glance, just like a person being led to be killed when he sees the gleaming sword that will end his life. He will not be able to stare at the sword, but he looks at it with a glance of the eye, in a state of lethargy and stealing glances.

At that time, the believers will say, "Indeed, the losers are those who have wronged themselves, so they are put into Hell and do not obtain even a little of the eternal blessings and pleasures in Paradise; they are separated from their loved ones, friends, and family." This is a loss without equal.

At the end of this verse, it is explained that the disbelievers will be in prolonged torment that has no end. There is no way for them to escape and avoid that torment.
text.46: This verse explains that a person will not receive help from anyone to save them from the torment that befalls them. The idols they once worshipped in the world cannot provide any assistance whatsoever; it is even impossible for them to defend them and release them from the punishment that is befalling them. This verse 46 concludes with a firm statement that those whom Allah allows to go astray have made it their character and nature to always commit evil, corruption, and violations against religious prohibitions; they can no longer be corrected, they can no longer do what is right and true in this world, and they will not be able to enter the Jannatun Na'im (Gardens of Delight) in the afterlife.
text.47:
Allah explains that He has commanded mankind to be obedient and compliant, and to accept the call of His Messenger, the religion of Allah which was conveyed before the coming of the Day which no one can restrain, reject, or hinder its arrival, that is the Day of Judgment. On that Day, they will not have any place to take refuge that will save them from hardship, and they will not be able to deny the evils they have committed in the world, because all of that is clearly recorded in the book of deeds of each individual, and their tongues and limbs will also bear witness. In any case, they will not be able to escape and avoid the horror of that Day. In this regard, Allah says:

"On that Day man will say, "Where is the escape?" No! There is no refuge! To your Lord is the destination that Day." (al-Qiyamah/75: 10-12)
text.48:
In this verse, Allah explains that if the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) has fulfilled his duty of conveying the message, calling the polytheists to the truth and the straight path, but they do not respond favorably and refuse to accept it, even rejecting and turning away from the truth, then the Messenger should leave their attitude alone without needing to be upset or anxious. This is because the Messenger was not tasked with monitoring and examining the deeds of those polytheists, but he was only tasked with conveying what Allah revealed and commanded him. If the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) has fulfilled his obligation, then he is considered to have fulfilled his mission, as Allah says:

"Then your duty is only to convey [the message], and it is We who will take account." (ar-Ra'd/13: 40)

And His saying:

"So remind, for you are only a reminder. You are not a manager over them." (al-Gasyiyah/88: 21-22)

And His saying also:

"Not upon you, [O Muhammad], is [responsibility for] their guidance, but Allah guides whom He wills." (al-Baqarah/2: 272)

Furthermore, Allah explains the nature and character of humans, which is that when humans are given wealth, blessed with the pleasures of life, physical well-being, and a sense of security, they are happy and joyful about these blessings, even often leading to feelings of arrogance and pride. But conversely, when they are afflicted with poverty, disease, various calamities in the form of floods, fires, and the consequences of sins and disobedience they commit, they deny all the blessings that Allah has given them, forgetting those blessings, and even forgetting to do good. Such is the nature of those who disbelieve and do not believe in Allah. This is different from those who truly believe in Allah; they are grateful, their faith and worship become more steadfast. If they do not or have not yet received blessings, they are patient because they believe in Allah's decree; everything is returned to Allah, they align themselves with Allah's word:

"And to Allah will [all] matters be returned." (al-Baqarah/2: 210)
text.49:
In this verse, Allah explains that He is the One who created the heavens and the earth, possesses them, has power and acts as He wills over what is in the heavens and the earth. Whatever He wills will surely come to pass and become reality, and what He does not will will not come to pass. He bestows blessings upon whomever He wills. No one can prevent what He wills, and no one can bestow blessings upon whom He does not will. He is the One who creates everything according to His will. He is the One who grants offspring of daughters to whomever He wills, grants offspring of sons to whomever He wills, and grants offspring of both sons and daughters, and there are also those whom He makes barren, without offspring, all of which has wisdom behind it.

All of this demonstrates the omnipotence of Allah, which no one can oppose. He acts as He wills in accordance with His decree, and no one is able to hinder Him or help regulate His will.

This verse is concluded with a firm statement that Allah is All-Knowing of who is worthy and deserving to be granted each type of bounty mentioned above. He is All-Powerful to create what He wills and act as He wills according to His wisdom and knowledge.
text.50:
In this verse, Allah explains that He is the One who created the heavens and the earth, possesses them, has power and acts as He wills over what is in the heavens and the earth. Whatever He wills will surely come to pass and become reality, and whatever He does not will will not come to pass. He bestows blessings upon whomever He wills. No one can prevent what He wills, and no one can bestow blessings upon whomever He does not will. He is the One who creates everything according to His will. He is the One who grants offspring of daughters to whomever He wills, grants offspring of sons to whomever He wills, and grants offspring of both sons and daughters, and there are also those whom He makes barren, without offspring, all of which has wisdom behind it.

All of this demonstrates the omnipotence of Allah, which no one can oppose. He acts as He wills in accordance with His nature, and no one is able to hinder Him or assist in regulating His desires.

This verse is concluded with an affirmation that Allah is All-Knowing of who is worthy and deserving to be granted each type of bounty mentioned above. He is All-Powerful to create what He wills and act as He wills according to His wisdom and knowledge.
text.51:
In this verse, Allah explains that He will not speak to His servants except in one of three ways, as follows:

1.  Through revelation (wahyu), that is, Allah instills into the heart of a prophet an understanding that he has no doubt is from Allah. This is what happened to Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him). His saying:

    "Indeed, the Holy Spirit (Ruhul Qudus) has breathed into my heart that no one will die until he has fully received his sustenance and his appointed time. So fear Allah and strive in the best possible way." (Narrated by Ibn Hibban)

2.  From behind a veil, that is, by hearing without seeing who is speaking, but the words are heard, as Allah spoke to Prophet Musa (Moses). Allah says:

    "And when Moses arrived at Our appointed time and his Lord spoke to him, he said, "My Lord, show me [Yourself] that I may look at You." [Allah] said, "You will not see Me..." (al-A'raf/7: 143)

3.  By sending a messenger, that is, Allah sends the Angel Jibril (Gabriel), and the messenger conveys the revelation to whomever He wills, as Jibril descended upon Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) and upon other prophets.

    'Aisha narrated that al-Harith bin Hisham asked the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), "How does revelation come to you?" The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) replied, "Sometimes it comes to me like the ringing of a bell. This is the most difficult for me. When it ceases, I have understood what has been said; sometimes the angel appears to me as a man, and he speaks to me, and I understand what he says." 'Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said, "Indeed, I saw the Prophet when revelation came to him on a very cold day, and after the revelation ceased, his forehead was dripping with sweat." (Narrated by al-Bukhari)

This verse concludes with the affirmation that Allah is the Most High and Most Holy from the attributes of His creation. He is described according to His wisdom, speaking to His servants, sometimes without intermediaries, whether in the form of inspiration or in the form of conversation from behind a veil.
text.52:
Allah explains that just as He sent down revelation to previous messengers, He also sent down revelation to the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, in the form of the Qur'an as His mercy. Furthermore, Allah explains that Muhammad, peace be upon him, before reaching the age of forty and while in the midst of his people, did not know what the Qur'an was and what faith was, nor did he know what the Sharia was in detail and the understanding of matters concerning the revelation that He sent down. But Allah made the Qur'an a bright light by which Allah guides the servants He wills and compares it to the true religion, which is Islam. As Allah says:

"And you did not expect that the Book would be conveyed to you, but [it is] as a mercy from your Lord. So never be an assistant to the disbelievers." (al-Qasas/28: 86)

And His saying:

"Say, "It is, for those who believe, a guidance and cure. And those who do not believe - in their ears is deafness, and it is upon them blindness." (Fussilat/41: 44)

Allah's saying:

"Indeed, this Qur'an guides to that which is most suitable." (al-Isra'/17: 9)

With the light of the Qur'an, Allah guides to the straight path, which is the true religion.
text.53:
In this verse, Allah explains that the straight path is the path that has been prescribed by Allah, the owner of the heavens and the earth, and the ruler of both, acting as He wills, and as the judge whose decisions cannot be challenged.

This verse concludes with a warning that all affairs of creation on the Day of Judgment will be returned to Allah, not to anyone else. Then each of them will be placed in the place that is appropriate for them, in Paradise or in Hell. Allah says:

And to Allah belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth. And to Allah will [all] matters be returned. (Ali 'Imran/3: 109)
